DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA

PBoC re-imposed reserve requirements on some FX options today according to sources, where new guidelines have been issued stating an additional reserve requirement will be applied to purchases and sales of options that bet on a decline in CNY. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May spokesman said the UK is making sure it has the right preparations in place to make sure the UK will prosper in the event of a no deal, while there were also comments from the EU that they are working constructively to reach a Brexit deal. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Union at Chile's Escondida copper mine said it was preparing a strike contingency plan, as it awaits the final response from BHP. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US is to reimpose Iranian sanctions tonight and is not looking to grant exemptions or waivers but will examine requests on a case-by-case basis. In related news, White House National Security Advisor Bolton said if Iran block the strait of Hormuz it would be their worst mistake although he does believe it is a bluff, while a senior US official stated its policy is to get as many countries as possible to reduce imports of Iranian crude to zero. (Newswires)

Iranian President Rouhani said Iran is open to negotiations as long as the US is sincere, while he added that talks alongside sanctions are meaningless and that the US must prove it is willing to solve problems through talks. Furthermore, Rouhani commented that practical actions are required from the EU to save the JCPOA and also warned the US will regret placing sanctions on Iran. (Newswires)
 

US

US President Trump stated that fixing the terrible trade deals for the US is a priority and going very well, while he also noted great financial numbers are being announced on almost a daily basis. (Newswires)

Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said there are many NAFTA subjects which still remain on the table and that he has sent his proposed Rules of Origin to the US who are studying it. Guajardo also stated he will return to Washington this week and that talks with Canada may take place next week depending upon the progress made this week. In related news, Mexico’s NAFTA chief negotiator Smith said Mexico will not accept anything that restricts agricultural trade and will not accept an automatic debt clause. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US stocks finished positive with the Nasdaq leading the upside while the S&P 500 notched a 3rd consecutive gain and moved to just over 20 points from all time highs. However, the gains were modest with volumes light and atypical of the post-NFP lull as well as due to summer. In terms of earnings, Newell Brands’ (NWL) sales missed Wall St’s revenue expectations but EPS came in higher than expected; the co also cut its FY18 forecasts. Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) traded higher after its earnings; revenues were higher than expectations, but EPS fell short. Jacob’s Engineering (JEC) almost hit a 10 year high after beats on both ends as well as raising its profit forecast for 2018. Elsewhere, Both T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) benefited from reports which said that regulators suggest the need for more competitors in the 5G complex which may boost the merger chances between the two network providers. Later, sources reported that DOJ officials were in early stage of reviewing T-Mobile (TMUS) deal to buy Sprint (S); regulators are said to think at least three US wireless carriers are needed, sources said. Elsewhere, Praxair (PX) were lower after the FTC said PX and Linde (LIN GY) may have to sell more assets than previously expected to gain antitrust approval. Linde announced it would consider more asset sales in order to get approval. Finally, Amcor confirmed Friday reports they are to acquire Bemis (BMS) for USD 6.8bln in an all-stock transaction, and Penn National Gamin (PENN) traded lower after William Hill (WMH LN) held talks with the co. as it looks to expand its market share in US sports betting. SPX +0.35% at 2851, NDX +0.59% at 7439 , DJI at +0.16% at 25503.

Treasuries remained in a tight range on Monday amid thin volumes across the complex, as the dog days of summer set in. Yields were mixed across the curve, but ultimately, close to the unchanged mark. The US Treasury will auction a total of USD 78bln in 3-year (USD 34bln, Tuesday), 10-year (USD 26bln, Wednesday) and 30-year (USD 18bln, Thursday), all to settle on 15 August; analysts at TD Securities note that USD38.2bln matures at the mid-month settlement, implying net supply of USD 33.8bln in new cash. TD also points out that USD 23.1bn matures on the Fed's balance sheet, and the Fed will allow USD 12.6bn to run-off, reinvesting USD 10.5bn, which will add-on USD 4.6bn to 3s, USD 3.5bn to the 10s, and USD 2.4bn to 30s. It is also worth noting that this series of auctions has a higher issuance amount, per the August refunding, though TD Securities believe that the drift higher in yields is likely to support demand. Looking to Tuesday’s auction of 3s, analysts at Barclays note that the sector saw healthy demand at the beginning of the year, but that has moderated, and the monthly bid-cover ratio fell from 3.1x in January to 2.5x at the July auction, with demand at 3-year the softest of all the tenors. In terms of participation, broker/dealer takedown has been edging up in 2018 at 3-year auctions, rising from 36% in January to 54% in July, which Barclays says is a function of smaller participation by investment funds. Barclays says that the 3-year WI roll is slightly rich when compared with previous auction cycles, given the larger add-ons (USD 4.6bln) and increased size at the upcoming auction. It also suggests that current on-the-run 3s trade slightly rich when compared to older 3s. US 10YR T-notes settled 4 ticks higher at 119-23+.

US MARKET WRAP – 6 Aug 2018: Iran open to negotiations, hours before US reimposes sanctions
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat, crude up, dollar up.
* REAR-VIEW: US announces it will re-impose sanctions on Iran; GBP hits YTD lows on Brexit no deal concerns.
* AHEAD: RBA rate decision (overnight); German industrial output; NZ GDT; 3yr Note Auction; Earnings from DIS, EMR.

* GEOPOLITICS: The German economy ministry said export and investment guarantees for transactions with Iran are still available for German companies, adding they remain in dialogue with the US on exemptions for German companies from sanctions. However, the US later said it will reimpose Iranian sanctions tonight, and it is not looking to grant exemptions or waivers, but will examine requests on a case-by-case basis; an official added that the administration’s policy is to get as many countries as possible to reduce imports of Iranian crude to zero. In later trade, Iran’s President Rouhani said Iran is open to negotiations as long as the US is sincere and added talks alongside sanctions are meaningless, urging the US to prove its willingness to solve problems through talks and the EU to provide practical actions necessary to save the nuclear deal. He warned the US will regret placing sanctions on Iran. The White House national security adviser said that if Iran was serious (in wanting to avoid sanctions) it would negotiate with the US, and warned that Iran blocking the Straits of Hormuz would be its “worst mistake”, though he suggested that Iran was bluffing on that threat. Later, Iranian President Rouhani said he was open to negotiations with the US, as long as it is “sincere”, adding that practical actions are required from the EU to save the JCPOA. Rouhani also threatened that the US would “regret” applying further sanctions on the nation.

* NAFTA: Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said there are many NAFTA subjects which still remain on the table; he has sent his proposed rules of origin to the US, and they are studying it and he will be returning to Washington in the middle of this week. Additionally, NAFTA Mexican negotiator Smith said Mexico will not accept anything that restricts agricultural trade as well as an automatic debt clause.

* BREXIT:  Following weekend reports that the EU was reportedly considering softening backstop powers for Northern Ireland to avert a no-deal Brexit, as outlined by a senior EU diplomat in the FT, the EU said on Monday to be working constructively to reach a Brexit deal. On the UK front, UK PM May spokesman said that the UK is making sure it has the right preparations in place for the UK to prosper in the event of a no deal. In other domestic news, officials were walking back from UK Trade Secretary’s comments over the weekend, that the ‘intransigent’ EU was making it difficult for the UK to reach a deal, suggesting that there was a 60% probability of a no deal outcome.

* FED SPEAK: Fed's Bullard (Dove, Non-Voter) said the yield curve inversion is a real possibility and noted US President Trump’s comments will not impact the FOMC.

* ECB SPEAK: ECB's Nowotny (Hawkish) said he supports the faster normalization of monetary policy. ECB’s Lautenschlager argued that she is comfortable with gradual hikes, so long as prices can sustainably move towards target.

* SPX +0.35% at 2851, NDX +0.59% at 7439 , DJI at +0.16% at 25503. SECTORS: Energy +0.3%, Materials +0.1%, Industrials +0.1%, Cons Discretionary +0.7%, Cons Staples +0.1%, Healthcare +0.1%, Financials +0.4%, Tech +0.6%, Telecoms -0.1%, Utilities +0.1%.

* EARNINGS: Newell Brands’ (NWL) sales missed Wall St’s revenue expectations but EPS came in higher than expected; the co also cut its FY18 forecasts. Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) traded higher after its earnings; revenues were higher than expectations, but EPS fell short. Jacob’s Engineering (JEC) almost hit a 10 year high after beats on both ends as well as raising its profit forecast for 2018.

* M&A: Both T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) benefited from reports which said that regulators suggest the need for more competitors in the 5G complex which may boost the merger chances between the two network providers. Later, sources reported that DOJ officials were in early stage of reviewing T-Mobile (TMUS) deal to buy Sprint (S); regulators are said to think at least three US wireless carriers are needed, sources said. Elsewhere, Praxair (PX) were lower after the FTC said PX and Linde (LIN GY) may have to sell more assets than previously expected to gain antitrust approval. Linde announced it would consider more asset sales in order to get approval. Finally, Amcor confirmed Friday reports they are to acquire Bemis (BMS) for USD 6.8bln in an all-stock transaction, and Penn National Gamin (PENN) traded lower after William Hill (WMH LN) held talks with the co. as it looks to expand its market share in US sports betting.

* WTI (U8) SETTLED $0.52 HIGHER AT $69.01; BRENT (V8) SETTLES $0.54 HIGHER AT $73.75. Crude starts the week on the front foot, with traders citing Friday’s reports that Saudi Arabia cut oil output in July, and Baker Hughes saw oil drillers cutting rigs for the second time in three weeks. On Monday, traders were also citing the US announcement to renew sanctions against Iran, with the “snap-back” sanctions set to be reinstated after midnight. Talks alongside sanctions are meaningless, and the US must prove it is willing to solve problems through talks. Traders seemed to dismiss the news that Saudi Arabia has resumed oil shipments through the Bab el-Mandeb Strait, after Houthi rebels halted attacks in the Red Sea in an effort to support peace efforts. Elsewhere, Iran is planning to lift oil production to more than 7.5mln BPD by 2024 (currently around 4.54mln), it’s oil minister said.

* US 10YR T-NOTES SETTLE 4 TICKS HIGHER AT 119-23+: Treasuries remained in a tight range on Monday amid thin volumes across the complex, as the dog days of summer set in. Yields were mixed across the curve, but ultimately, close to the unchanged mark. The US Treasury will auction a total of USD 78bln in 3-year (USD 34bln, Tuesday), 10-year (USD 26bln, Wednesday) and 30-year (USD 18bln, Thursday), all to settle on 15 August; analysts at TD Securities note that USD38.2bln matures at the mid-month settlement, implying net supply of USD 33.8bln in new cash. TD also points out that USD 23.1bn matures on the Fed's balance sheet, and the Fed will allow USD 12.6bn to run-off, reinvesting USD 10.5bn, which will add-on USD 4.6bn to 3s, USD 3.5bn to the 10s, and USD 2.4bn to 30s. It is also worth noting that this series of auctions has a higher issuance amount, per the August refunding, though TD Securities believe that the drift higher in yields is likely to support demand. Looking to Tuesday’s auction of 3s, analysts at Barclays note that the sector saw healthy demand at the beginning of the year, but that has moderated, and the monthly bid-cover ratio fell from 3.1x in January to 2.5x at the July auction, with demand at 3-year the softest of all the tenors. In terms of participation, broker/dealer takedown has been edging up in 2018 at 3-year auctions, rising from 36% in January to 54% in July, which Barclays says is a function of smaller participation by investment funds. Barclays says that the 3-year WI roll is slightly rich when compared with previous auction cycles, given the larger add-ons (USD 4.6bln) and increased size at the upcoming auction. It also suggests that current on-the-run 3s trade slightly rich when compared to older 3s.

* USD: The DXY got to within striking distance of its 2018 peak at 95.523 vs 95.652 before running out of steam. Latest CFTC data shows IMM Dollar longs only marginally pared from 18-month peaks and still just over $20bln. 

* GBP, TRY: The GBP continues to weaken in wake of last week’s BoE policy meeting on a combination of ‘dovish’ rate guidance and concern about a no deal or hard Brexit. UK Trade Secretary Fox believes the prospects of the UK leaving without an agreement with the EU are now less than even (60-40 to be precise), and Cable has hit new ytd lows of 1.2920 in response, with only minor support around 1.2910 protecting the next big figure on the downside. Meanwhile, EURGBP is grinding above 0.8900 again irrespective of independent declines in the single currency. However, the TRY is suffering even more than the G10 laggard and has extended losses through 5.0000 vs the USD to breach 5.3 to the upside as US sanctions over the detention of Pastor Brunson add to Turkey’s economic and fiscal woes. Note, however, the CBRT has attempted to stem the tide via a cut in the foreign currency reserve option to 40% from 45% previously.

* CHF, CAD: USDCHF is heading back towards parity (and EURCHF has recovered 1.1500+ status) and USDCAD has now rebounded further from last Friday’s post-NFP breaching 1.3000 amidst broad Greenback strength after the initial disappointment of sub-forecast headline payrolls.

* AUD, NZD: Both softer ahead of RBA (Tuesday) and RNBZ (Thursday) policy meetings this week that are widely expected to see the respective Central Banks maintain benchmark rates, and signal unchanged policy for even longer. AUDUSD has backed off 0.7400 again to circa 0.7380 and the Kiwi is testing 0.6730 as the cross hovers above 1.0950.

* EUR, JPY: The single currency has managed to stave off offers ahead of its 2018 base vs the Dollar and supply into bids said to be protecting that level at 1.1520 with a bounce off the 1.1530 Monday session low to 1.1550. However, this may yet be a temporary stay of execution as USDJPY extends its range to the upside and absorbs some offers at 111.50.

* YUAN: More signs of official intervention after ‘direct’ devaluation and another higher PBoC USDCNY mid-point fix overnight, as ‘sources’ claim that some currency options may be subject to bigger reserve margins to discourage speculation against the Yuan. Note, these derivatives are currently subject to a 10% margin and the new 20% reserve for FX Forwards came into effect today.

* COMING-UP – RBA. Policy announcement due at 0530BST/2330CDT. The RBA is set to decide on rates this Tuesday, and expectations remain one-sided for the central bank to keep the Cash Rate Target at the record low 1.50% where it has been for 2 years. This is reflected in ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures which price in 100% expectations for no change in rates and with its associated implied yield curve suggesting August 2019 as the earliest date for a hike. The RBA hasn't provided any fresh rhetoric to change the outlook for the central bank since the last meeting, where it continued to reiterate that the board judged it was appropriate to maintain policy, while it also repeated the next rate move is likely to be a hike if economy improves as expected, although it saw no strong case for a near-term change. UBS Weekly FX Flows report: USD recorded strong inflows while GBP was sold despite BoE tightening
content: USD was the most bought G10 currency on a normalized basis, experiencing its heaviest inflows on Friday, coinciding with the July labour market report and the PBoC's announcement to impose a 20% reserve requirement on FX forwards positions. CAD was bid for a second straight week while AUD was bought amid a clutch of positive macro data. SEK registered net buying interest as GDP data on Monday boosted inflows while NOK was marginally bid in a relatively light data week. GBP was the most sold G10 currency, with heavy outflows around the BoE meeting despite the interest rate hike. JPY saw outflows, with considerable selling coinciding with the BoJ policy adjustment to widen 10y JGB trading band and introduce new forward guidance on Tuesday. EUR was sold for a second straight week with the heaviest selling on Friday. NZD also saw outflows for the second week in a row amid weak sentiment data.

DJIA

  • American Express (AXP) – The co. and GreenSky have entered into a strategic alliance to improve digital payments to help merchants grow their businesses. (Newswires)
  • Apple (AAPL) – New iPhones shipments may be delayed after a virus outbreak was reported at Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), though the impact is expected to be limited given the co. was prepared for disruptions. Separately, Foxconn may add assembly lines at the Wisconsin plant for iPhone production to help Apple avoid tariff risks arising due to US-Sino tensions. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The bank is planning to name Jim Esposito as co-head of its trading unit. (WSJ)

S&P500

  • AT&T (T) – The co. reportedly made overpayments to former workers, and is now said to be requesting repayments from overpaid pensioners. (WSJ)
  • Bank of America (BAC) – The bank is mulling moving its research analysts from London to Paris, raising worries over London’s future as a financial centre. (FT)
  • BlackRock (BLK) –Ocwen Financial founder Bill Erbey accused BlackRock of carrying out accelerated foreclosure action against American subprime borrowers which were in difficulty after the financial crisis. (FT)
  • CBS (CBS) – The co.’s president Kelly Kahl defended the network stating the co. is committed to a safe workplace amid allegations of sexual misconduct against CEO Moonves. (Newswires)
  • Gilead (GILD) - The China National Drug Administration has approved Genvoya fort the treatment of HIV-1 infection. (Newswires)
  • Kraft Heinz (KHC) – The co, is narrowing down its list of bidders for the sales of a USD 1bln Indian portfolio; according to people familiar with the matter. (Newswires)
  • Marathon Petroleum (MPC)/Andeavor (ANDV) – The two have submitted a definitive proxy statement over the merger agreement under which MPC is to acquire all Andeavor’s outstanding shares. (Newswires)
  • Newell Brands (NWL) – The co. cuts its FY18 operating cash flow view to USD 0.9bln - 1.2bln. (Newswires)   
  • Nucor (NUE)/US Steel (X) – The two firms have successfully blocked hundreds of requests made by companies for tariff exemptions. (NYT)
  • PepsiCo (PEP) - CEO is to leave the position with Ramon Laguarta to succeed; effective October 3rd. Current CEO, Indra Nooyi, will remain as chairman until early next year. Laguarta has been president of the co. since September 2017. (Newswires)
  • Praxair (PX) – The FTC said the co. and Linde (LIN GY) may have to sell more assets than expected to get antitrust approval for their USD 87bln deal. This has been seen a roadblock to the deal getting completed. (Newswires)
  • Regeneron (REGN) – The co. announced a collaboration with Bluebird Bio (BLUE) for the development and commercialisation of the new immune cell therapies for the treatment of cancer. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) – The bank is said to be facing a federal probe over how it managed low income housing tax credits. Separately, the co. reported that hundreds of customers have lost their homes due to a technical glitch which saw the mortgage loan modification underwriting tool identifying a calculation error that affected certain accounts. (Newswires)

  • Barron’s negative on CBS (CBS)

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The tech giant is in talks with Tencent (TCEHY) and other Chinese firms for the introduction of its cloud business in China. (Newswires)

  • JD.com (JD) – The co. launched its first store with no cashier in Jakarta, Indonesia which operates in a similar way to its rival Alibaba’s (BABA) cashierless stores. (China Money Network)
  • Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) – The co. must make a Sky (SKY LN) bid north of GBP 26bln by the end of Thursday to counter Comcast's (CMCSA) bid. (Sky News)

  • Alibaba (BABA) – The co.’s communication app DingTalk has become the largest chat services for firms with more than 100mln users and 7mln employees across China although it is facing backlash from Chinese workers stating it creates an unhealthy working culture. (Newswires)

  • LaSalle Hotel (LHO) – The co. filed an investor presentation in connection with Blackstone (BX) deal. (Newswires)
  • Manpower (MAN) – The co. announced a new 6mln share stock repurchase programme. COO Darryl Green is to retire; effective August 31st. (Newswires)

content: It’s been an incredibly slow grind, and in extremely light summer volumes, but Gilts continue to drag Bunds back up from early lows to new intraday highs at 122.95 and 162.19 respectively (+21 ticks vs -17 ticks at one stage and +14 ticks vs -22 ticks). The 10 year EU debt futures are basically trading inversely with the Gbp and Eur vs a dominant Usd in the FX space across the board, with EMs like the Try sliding even further, but Cable down to fresh ytd lows (around 1.2933) and Eur/Usd very close to its 2018 base (1.1530 vs 1.1510). Back to bonds, and Gilts face resistance beyond 123.00 around 123.39, while market contacts are flagging 162.13 as a key technical level for Bunds on a closing basis.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 6th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Cable probing 11-month lows as UK Trade Minister Fox cites 60% chance of “no deal Brexit”; USDTRY pushes to new record high of 5.1800
  • Oil spiking higher and up on the day on reduced supply, equities initially lower but push into positive territory in a news-thin morning
  • Scarce calendar ahead with no tier 1 data or scheduled events to look forward to

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly positive as bourses followed suit from Friday’s gains on Wall St, although upside was limited as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s key events including China’s tariff retaliation list announcement and the mixed US jobs data. ASX 200 (+0.6%) was led higher by commodity-related stocks and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was positive but with upside limited by recent JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) were mixed as the mainland failed to hold on to early gains due to trade uncertainty and further PBoC inaction. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet overnight but still edged mild gains as yields slightly eased from last week’s BoJ-triggered surge, while reports also noted that the BoJ bought a record amount of 5yr-10yr JGBs last week in its efforts to cap gains in yields.

China state media commented that China is prepared for a long trade battle with the US, while it also noted that US is escalating trade friction with China and is turning international trade as a zero-sum game. In addition, China state media said President Trump is starring in his own carefully orchestrated Street Fighter-style deceitful drama and wants others to play along which is wishful thinking. (Newswires/Xinhua/Twitter)

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8513 (Prev. 6.8322)

EU/UK/US

UK Trade Secretary Fox said the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit is increasing in which he blamed the "intransigence" of the European Commission. Fox also placed the chances of leaving the EU without a deal at "60-40" and stated that EU Chief Negotiator Barnier dismissed the UK's Chequers proposals simply because "we have never done it before". This also comes alongside commentary in the Sunday Times over the weekend that businesses and investors are scrambling to protect themselves against a plunge in the value of the pound if Britain crashes out of the EU in March. (BBC/Sunday Times) However, there were later reports that UK PM May is said to be confident of reaching a Brexit agreement according to sources who insisted there is only a very small probability of failing to reach an agreement with the EU. (Guardian)

EU is reportedly considering softening backstop powers for Northern Ireland to avert a no-deal Brexit, according to a senior EU diplomat. (FT)

UK Chancellor Hammond has warned senior figures in the City that France could attempt to bind Britain’s financial services sector in red tape post-Brexit, leading to a potential loss of access to European markets. (FT)

ECB's Lautenschlaeger (Hawk) stated it would be wrong for the central bank to abruptly change monetary policy direction which would not help the economy nor price stability. Lautenschlaeger also stated she is very much in favour of normalizing monetary policy which means gradually raising interest rates and that the pre-condition is that the path to price stability is sustainably strengthened. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea Foreign Minister Ri described US actions as alarming in response after US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged other countries to keep up sanctions pressure on Pyongyang. In addition, a UN report stated that North Korea has not halted its nuclear and missile program which is in violation of sanctions. (BBC/Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted on Saturday “Iran, and its economy, is going very bad and fast! I will meet, or not meet, it doesn’t matter – it’s up to them… Iran Is messing with the wrong President”. Furthermore, US Secretary of State Pompeo said the White House will make an announcement detailing reinstatement of some Iran sanctions on Monday. Note: The first round of Iran sanctions imposed by the US to come into effect on Tuesday – the Iranian government will no longer be able to purchase US banknotes and broad sanctions will be imposed on Iranian industries. (Twitter/Newswires)

Venezuela said there was an assassination attempt on President Maduro by far-right opponents after several drones armed with explosives blew up near President Maduro, while reports also noted Maduro was unharmed and that 7 people were being treated for injuries. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equites opened the week modestly lower (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%) as trade concerns weighed on indices initially. Most major European indices were in the red, with the DAX leading the losses and breaking through its 100DMA (12,582) to the downside following Linde (-3.5%) announcing that they and Praxair may need to shed more assets to get antitrust approval, casting doubt over the viability of their merger. The losses in the DAX and Euro Stoxx were short-lived, however, seeing choppy trade and paring back early losses into positive territory on no fundamental catalyst in a news-thin day.

The materials sector (-1.2%) is underperforming on the back of softer base metals, as the US-Sino trade spat continues to weigh on the market.

HSBC (-0.4%) reported earnings, where the bank highlighted rising expenses alongside a civil penalty of USD 765mln.

William Hill (+0.3%) have reportedly entered into talks with US casino “giant” Penn National Gaming that would provide the co. with a greater share of the US sports betting market.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts returned to Liffe on the back foot, albeit modestly between 122.71-57 vs their previous 122.74 settlement, and in relatively subdued trade at the start of the new week with little on the domestic agenda bar Halifax house prices. The Short Sterling strip was also moderately softer off the open, but only a tick offside at worst after last week’s net gains beyond the very front end of the curve following the BoE rate hike and guidance signalling no further tightening this year. Moreover, Governor Carney underlined Brexit contingency and concerns about no deal that could prompt the MPC to change course on policy, and comments from Trade Secretary Fox over the weekend chime with his view that the risk of that scenario is rising. Hence, the 10 year UK has subsequently rebounded to 122.86 and 3 month contracts are flat to 1 tick ahead presently, while Bunds have reclaimed 162.00+ status and a marginal new Eurex high at 162.16 vs. 161.83 at worst and US Treasuries remain largely side-lined with the curve marginally flatter.

FX

GBP - More negative news for the Pound as UK Trade Secretary Fox claims that the risk of a no deal Brexit has risen to 60% after EU chief negotiator Barnier rejected the Chequers White Paper, with Cable back down through 1.3000 and hitting marginal new lows around 1.2950, while Eur/Gbp is back above 0.8900 even though the single currency is relatively weak in its own right. Note also, a major US bank has initiated a short Cable trade at 1.2986, looking for 1.2700 and with a 1.3150 stop, while market contacts suggest stops are likely if the aforementioned ytd base is breached from 1.2950.

TRY - The Lira remains under heavy pressure and one of if not the EM underperformer again as Usd/Try soars further above 5.0000 to almost 5.1600 and fresh all-time highs. The catalyst, ongoing US-Turkey diplomatic strains due to Pastor Brunson on top of the latter’s domestic political situation and investor angst over the economy, perceived Government interference with the CBRT and a whole lot more.

CAD/CHF - Back to the G10 and the next biggest losers after Sterling, with the Loonie back under 1.3000 vs its US rival due to Canada’s row with Saudi Arabia over an activist being held in the Kingdom. Meanwhile, the Franc is straddling 0.9950 vs the Greenback, but firmer again vs the Eur around 1.1500, which will keep the SNB fully monitoring the situation and ready to maintain a dovish stance on policy (to recap, Jordan said last Friday that the Bank has more room to cut rates if needed).

EUR/NZD/AUD/JPY - All holding up relatively well vs a bid Dollar in general (DXY over 95.300 and still poised for a test of 95.652 highs for the year so far), but the Eur only just keeping its head above 1.1550 and layered bids down to 1.1520 ahead of the 2018 low (1.1510), while the Kiwi remains under 0.6750 and is lagging its antipodean counterpart that is holding firm after PBoC Yuan intervention near 0.7400 and circa 1.0975 on the cross ahead of the RBA policy meeting tomorrow (full preview available via our headline feed). Usd/Jpy is very rangebound again between 111.15-35 with bids at 111.00 and offers at 111.50, 111.60 and 111.73, according to market observers.

COMMODITIES

Oil is higher on the day with WTI +0.7% and Brent +0.7% amid a Saudi crude output cut on Friday alongside the US rig count falling for the second time in three weeks, seeing a decline of 4 to 1044.

Russia’s energy minister Novak reported that future output is to be in line with the OPEC+ 1mln BPD boost plan.

The EU said that other signatories are committed to the continuation of Iranian exports of oil and gas

In the metals scope, gold is essentially unmoved and is still languishing around 17-month lows, currently trading at USD 1211.90/oz. London Copper has fallen for the 3rd session in 4 as trade concerns weigh on the construction material. Zinc is also faring poorly and has fallen 2.2%, with Shanghai lead also down 1.4%.

content: • WTI and Brent Sept'18 futures also moved to session highs with WTI testing USD 69.50/bbl to the upside and Brent breaching USD 74.00/bbl to the upside

FX Morning Colour: Cable on the brink, Lira over the edge
content:
GBP

More negative news for the Pound as UK Trade Secretary Fox claims that the risk of a no deal Brexit has risen to 60% after EU chief negotiator Barnier rejected the Chequers White Paper, with Cable back down through 1.3000 and almost testing previous 2018 lows around 1.2958, while Eur/Gbp is back above 0.8900 even though the single currency is relatively weak in its own right. Note also, a major US bank has initiated a short Cable trade at 1.2986, looking for 1.2700 and with a 1.3150 stop, while market contacts suggest stops are likely if the aforementioned ytd base is breached from 1.2950.

TRY

The Lira remains under heavy pressure and one of if not the EM underperformer again as Usd/Try soars further above 5.0000 to almost 5.1500 and fresh all time highs. The catalyst, ongoing US-Turkey diplomatic strains due to Pastor Brunson on top of the latter’s domestic political situation and investor angst over the economy, perceived Government interference with the CBRT and a whole lot more.

CAD/CHF

Back to the G10 and the next biggest losers after Sterling, with the Loonie back under 1.3000 vs its US rival due to Canada’s row with Saudi Arabia over an activist being held in the Kingdom. Meanwhile, the Franc is straddling 0.9950 vs the Greenback, but firmer again vs the Eur around 1.1500, which will keep the SNB fully monitoring the situation and ready to maintain a dovish stance on policy (to recap, Jordan said last Friday that the Bank has more room to cut rates if needed).

EUR/NZD/AUD/JPY

All holding up relatively well vs a bid Dollar in general (DXY over 95.300 and still poised for a test of 95.652 highs for the year so far), but the Eur only just keeping its head above 1.1550 and layered bids down to 1.1520 ahead of the 2018 low (1.1510), while the Kiwi remains under 0.6750 and is lagging its antipodean counterpart that is holding firm after PBoC Yuan intervention near 0.7400 and circa 1.0975 on the cross ahead of the RBA policy meeting tomorrow (full preview available via our headline feed). Usd/Jpy is very rangebound again between 111.15-35 with bids at 111.00 and offers at 111.50, 111.60 and 111.73, according to market observers.

content: Gilts returned to Liffe on the back foot, albeit modestly between 122.71-57 vs their previous 122.74 settlement, and in relatively subdued trade at the start of the new week with little on the domestic agenda bar Halifax house prices. The Short Sterling strip was also moderately softer off the open, but only a tick offside at worst after last week’s net gains beyond the very front end of the curve following the BoE rate hike and guidance signalling no further tightening this year. Moreover, Governor Carney underlined Brexit contingency and concerns about no deal that could prompt the MPC to change course on policy, and comments from Trade Secretary Fox over the weekend chime with his view that the risk of that scenario is rising. Hence, the 10 year UK has subsequently nudged up to flat and 3 month contracts are flat to 1 tick ahead presently.

Bunds: indecisive, and ignoring awful German factory orders
content: The 10 year German debt future is straddling 162.00 in early Eurex trade and looking rather lacklustre even though there are fundamental reasons to support the benchmark given significantly weaker than expected industrial orders data. However, Bunds were actually marked down off the open to 162.01 vs last Friday’s 162.05 close and dipped a bit further below the big figure to 161.95 before finding some underlying bids to trade up at 162.13, but are now back in the red and slipping to fresh lows at 161.84. Core bonds may be acknowledging a partial recovery or some stability in Italian BTPs after last week’s rout and underperformance on concerns about the budget meeting in Rome and more speculation about Finance Minister Tria potentially clashing with other Government ministers. Note, the 10 year Italian benchmark is currently ¾ point or so above parity around 125.77.

**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS** 

6th August 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly positive as bourses followed suit from Friday’s gains on Wall St, although upside was limited as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s key events including China’s tariff retaliation list announcement and the mixed US jobs data. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was led higher by commodity-related stocks and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was positive but with upside limited by recent JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) were mixed as the mainland failed to hold on to early gains due to trade uncertainty and further PBoC inaction. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet overnight but still edged mild gains as yields slightly eased from last week’s BoJ-triggered surge, while reports also noted that the BoJ bought a record amount of 5yr-10yr JGBs last week in its efforts to cap gains in yields.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 6th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets initially followed suit from Friday’s gains on Wall St, although upside was limited by ongoing US-China trade tensions
  • UK Trade Secretary Fox has placed the chances of leaving the EU without a deal at "60-40"
  • Looking ahead, today sees a lack of tier 1 releases

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly positive as bourses followed suit from Friday’s gains on Wall St, although upside was limited as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s key events including China’s tariff retaliation list announcement and the mixed US jobs data. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was led higher by commodity-related stocks and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was positive but with upside limited by recent JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) were mixed as the mainland failed to hold on to early gains due to trade uncertainty and further PBoC inaction. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet overnight but still edged mild gains as yields slightly eased from last week’s BoJ-triggered surge, while reports also noted that the BoJ bought a record amount of 5yr-10yr JGBs last week in its efforts to cap gains in yields.

China state media commented that China is prepared for a long trade battle with the US, while it also noted that US is escalating trade friction with China and is turning international trade as a zero-sum game. In addition, China state media said President Trump is starring in his own carefully orchestrated Street Fighter-style deceitful drama and wants others to play along which is wishful thinking. (Newswires/Xinhua/Twitter)

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8513 (Prev. 6.8322)


UK/EU

UK Trade Secretary Fox said the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit is increasing in which he blamed the "intransigence" of the European Commission. Fox also placed the chances of leaving the EU without a deal at "60-40" and stated that EU Chief Negotiator Barnier dismissed the UK's Chequers proposals simply because "we have never done it before". This also comes alongside commentary in the Sunday Times over the weekend that businesses and investors are scrambling to protect themselves against a plunge in the value of the pound if Britain crashes out of the EU in March. (BBC/Sunday Times) However, there were later reports that UK PM May is said to be confident of reaching a Brexit agreement according to sources who insisted there is only a very small probability of failing to reach an agreement with the EU. (Guardian)

EU is reportedly considering softening backstop powers for Northern Ireland to avert a no-deal Brexit, according to a senior EU diplomat. (FT)

UK Chancellor Hammond has warned senior figures in the City that France could attempt to bind Britain’s financial services sector in red tape post-Brexit, leading to a potential loss of access to European markets. (FT)

UK Treasury has reportedly asked large institutions in the financial sector for help prioritise which pieces of financial regulation are the most crucial in their Brexit action plan. (Financial News London)

UK Business confidence declined significantly amid Brexit uncertainty according to two survey. A poll of the FTSE 350 business by ICSA found that 55% of company board members are predicting a decline in their business over the comer year compared to 24% six-months ago (when the group last surveyed them). (The Guardian) 

ECB's Lautenschlaeger (Hawk) stated it would be wrong for the central bank to abruptly change monetary policy direction which would not help the economy nor price stability. Lautenschlaeger also stated she is very much in favour of normalizing monetary policy which means gradually raising interest rates and that the pre-condition is that the path to price stability is sustainably strengthened. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Germany at AAA; Outlook Stable and raised Czech Republic from A+ to AA-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets were range-bound overnight in which the DXY remained near the prior week’s highs above 95.00, while its counterparts languished with EUR/USD below 1.1600 and GBP/USD breached 1.3000 to the downside amid continued Brexit woes. There were comments over the weekend from UK Trade Secretary Fox that the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit is increasing and who placed the chances of leaving the EU without a deal at 60%, although Whitehall sources later contradicted this and stated UK PM May is confident of reaching a Brexit agreement and insisted there is only a very small probability of not reaching a deal. Elsewhere, CAD briefly wobbled on reports that Saudi Arabia froze all trade investment with Canada and halted diplomatic ties in a dispute over the arrest of a women’s rights activist, although CAD later pared the losses given its relatively small exposure the middle-east nation and as high-beta currencies were briefly supported from a bout of CNY strength at the reopen.

Saudi Arabia froze all trade investment with Canada and declared that that the Canadian envoy in Riyadh is unwelcome in which it considered the Canadian Ambassador persona non grata, while the Saudi Foreign Affairs Ministry also recalled its Ambassador to Canada. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly flat although WTI crude futures saw marginal gains as it continued its bounce from support at USD 68.00/bbl. Elsewhere, gold was relatively unchanged amid a lack of drivers and as the greenback held steady in Asia trade, while price action in copper was also muted amid underperformance in mainland China due to ongoing trade tensions.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (3 Aug) Total rigs fell by 4 to 1044 rigs. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea Foreign Minister Ri described US actions as alarming in response after US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged other countries to keep up sanctions pressure on Pyongyang. In addition, a UN report stated that North Korea has not halted its nuclear and missile program which is in violation of sanctions. (BBC/Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted on Saturday “Iran, and its economy, is going very bad and fast! I will meet, or not meet, it doesn’t matter – it’s up to them… Iran Is messing with the wrong President”. Furthermore, US Secretary of State Pompeo said the White House will make an announcement detailing reinstatement of some Iran sanctions on Monday. Note: The first round of Iran sanctions imposed by the US to come into effect on Tuesday – the Iranian government will no longer be able to purchase US banknotes and broad sanctions will be imposed on Iranian industries. (Twitter/Newswires)

Venezuela said there was an assassination attempt on President Maduro by far-right opponents after several drones armed with explosives blew up near President Maduro, while reports also noted Maduro was unharmed and that 7 people were being treated for injuries. (Newswires)
 

US

There were further reports of short-covering after traders were positioned for a better NFP headline based on the ADP data released on Wednesday, IGM said. The complex was also buoyed by a ramping up of trade tensions (this time, from the Chinese side). The net result was a slightly flatter curve, with major curve spreads little changed. US 10YR T-notes settled 9 ticks higher at 119-19+.

US President Trump stated that tariffs are working and that the US will be able to begin reducing large amounts of its USD 21tln debt due to tariffs. In separate news, US President Trump was also said to be reserving the right to impose tariffs on Canadian-produced autos. (Newswires/Twitter)

White House spokesperson said on Friday that the US has had a high level of discussions with China on trade over the past few months and noted they are open to having further conversations. However, there were also comments from a senior US administration official that there has been zero engagement between US president Trump & China, apart from one call in the last few days which resolved nothing. (Newswires)

ASX 200 (+0.6%) is led higher by commodity-related stocks and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) is also positive but with upside limited by recent JPY strength, while Isuzu and NTT are among the best performers with the former underpinned by earnings and NTT planning to combine its units into an IT giant. - PBoC raised the reserve requirement on FX forwards trading to 20%, while it stated it will take counter cyclical measures to keep FX markets stable based on market condition and that it will also keep the yuan "basically stable". (Newswires)
Note: The PBoC had previously cut the reserve requirement on FX forwards to 0% from 20% in September last year which some suggested was an effort to stem the yuan's appreciation.

Trade News
- China released their potential retaliation list to US tariff threats on Friday and are to impose differentiated tariffs on approximately USD 60bln US goods. China said the measures are to guard its interest as well as keep trade frictions from escalating and noted that import tax rates will range from 5%, 10% and 25%. Furthermore, China stated the government reserve the right for additional retaliation measures, while the proposed retaliatory tariff list by China includes some US aircraft, chemical products, wine, semiconductors, auto parts, lumber, iron ore, steel products, LNG, dried beef and soybean oil. (Newswires)
- China state media commentary stated that US administration’s extreme pressure and blackmail are clear to the world but added that these methods will not be fruitful against China. (Xinhua)
- White House spokesperson said on Friday that the US has had a high level of discussions with China on trade over the past few months and noted they are open to having further conversations. However, there were also comments from a senior US administration official that there has been zero engagement between US president Trump & China, apart from one call in the last few days which resolved nothing. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE NEWS: Nanya Tech July sales rose 90% Y/Y, OCBC Q2 net rose 16% Y/Y
content:
TAIWAN

Largan (3008 TT)
- Co. July revenue rose nearly 20% Y/Y to TWD 5.33bln which was also an 8-month high. (Taipei Times)

Nanya Technology (2408 TT)
- Co. July sales rose 90% Y/Y to TWD 8.16bln. (Newswires)

Realtek Semiconductor (2379 TT)
- Co. July revenue TWD 3.86bln vs. Prev. TWD 3.43bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

TSMC (2330 TT)
- Co. shut down factories following a virus attack and stated that Q3 revenues will be impacted by 3% and gross margins by 1% citing costs and shipment delays. (Newswires)

Other News
- Taiwan may relax restrictions on insurance companies’ investment in stocks. (Newswires)
 

SINGAPORE

Keppel Corp (KEP SP)
- Co. to partner with Vicinity regarding a AUD 1bln Australian property fund. (Newswires)

Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (MUST SP)
- Co. Q2 net property income SGD 20mln vs. Prev. SGD 12mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

OCBC (OCBS SP)
- Co. Q2 net rose 16% Y/Y SGD 1.2bln vs. Exp. SGD 1.1bln, NII rose 8% to SGD 1.45bln vs. Prev. SGD 1.35bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Pacc Offshore Services Holdings (POSH SP)
- Claimant Kensteel Engineering has discontinued action against the Co. (Newswires)

Raffles Medical Group (RFMD SP)
- Co. Q2 net SGD 16.9mln vs. Prev. SGD 16.8mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

UOL Group (UOL SP)
- Q2 net SGD 132.7mln vs. Prev. SGD 121.8mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

subject: Rusal (486 HK) Q2 Adj. net USD 218mln vs. Prev. USD 202mln Y/Y

Asia begins the week with a slight positive tone following the mild gains on Wall St last Friday where earnings continued to underpin sentiment and participants digested mixed jobs data as NFP missed but saw a firm upward revision & Unemployment fell
